image.altText: A young Aboriginal woman wears showjumping gear and holds the reins of a black horse. She is looking away from the camera

items.synopsis: Sixteen-year-old Lalwa May will soon become the first Indigenous showjumper to compete in international competition when she competes at the French National Championships.

title.children: First Indigenous showjumper to make horse riding history overseas

image.altText: An old chair with metal legs and a wooden seat and back sits on the dirty floor of a basement. A cobweb extends between corners

items.synopsis: In a basement in a Ukrainian village on the Russian border, the remnants of a torture chamber tell a horrifying tale. Those investigating what happened here say the depraved orders came from the top. WARNING: Readers might find the details in this story distressing.

title.children: When Russians came looking for Vyacheslav, he had already fled. So they took his mum to the torture chamber

image.altText: Close-up of man

items.synopsis: Ben Roberts-Smith has lost one of the most expensive defamation trials in Australia, and along with it his reputation. There are other factors that now need to be considered too.

title.children: Here's what comes next for Ben Roberts-Smith after losing his defamation battle and reputation

image.altText: Fat, cholesterol and other substances build up in the walls of the arteries, restricting blood flow.

items.synopsis: Peripheral artery disease is described as a "silent killer", but women don't always show traditional symptoms, which is leading to underdiagnosis.

title.children: Danielle was given a choice — her leg or her life. She wants others to recognise the signs of this 'silent killer'

image.altText: A large circular CSIRO logo on the side of a building.

items.synopsis: The payment error was revealed by Greens senator David Shoebridge, who asked CSIRO chief executive Larry Marshall about the overpayment during Senate Estimates.

title.children: CSIRO deputy chair David Knox overpaid by $200,000, money still unrecovered

image.altText: Charlie Wade stands on a pier

items.synopsis: English backpacker Charlie Wade was surprised when a girl he met on Snapchat asked him to send a nude photo. Her next message left him in a state of shock.

title.children: Charlie is one of a growing number of young men falling victim to 'sextortion' scams — he wants you to learn from his mistakes

image.altText: Two photos: A bald man with glasses wearing a suit, next to a photo of a man with hair and no glasses wearing a suit

items.synopsis: This is The Loop, your quick catch-up for this morning's stories as they happen.

title.children: Dutton calls Roberts-Smith ruling a 'tough day', Joe Biden falls, and potatoes cause road chaos. Catch up with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Opposition Leader Peter Dutton says yesterday's court ruling against war veteran Ben Roberts-Smith was a "tough day for the country", and believes there has been a "significant culture change" at the Australian Defence Force. A defamation case brought by Roberts-Smith against three newspapers was dismissed, after the court found defences of substantial or contextual truth had been established over alleged unlawful killings, bullying and domestic violence. Dutton tells Nine's Today show that most Australians hold the Victoria Cross recipient's former SAS regiment in the highest regard, and he believes there has been enormous change in that regiment since Roberts-Smith's time. "I think there has been a significant culture change over the last half a dozen years at least," he says. "You go to visit the regiment in Perth now, there are very few people there who even served in Afghanistan or were involved in conflicts in the Middle East. "The next generation, even one removed, now are serving in the SAS."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Dutton says Ben Roberts-Smith ruling was a 'tough day for the country'

props.alt: A bald man with glasses wearing a suit, next to a photo of a man with hair and no glasses wearing a suit

children.content: Peter Dutton and Ben Roberts-Smith.
(ABC News / AAP)
Opposition Leader Peter Dutton says yesterday's court ruling against war veteran Ben Roberts-Smith was a "tough day for the country", and
believes there has been a "significant culture change" at the Australian Defence Force.
A defamation case brought by Roberts-Smith against three newspapers was dismissed, after the court
found defences of substantial or contextual truth had been established over alleged unlawful killings, bullying and domestic violence

Dutton tells Nine's Today show that most Australians hold the Victoria Cross recipient's former SAS regiment in the highest regard, and he believes there has been enormous change in that regiment since Roberts-Smith's time.
"I think there has been a significant culture change over the last half a dozen years at least," he says.
"You go to visit the regiment in Perth now, there are very few people there who even served in Afghanistan or were involved in conflicts in the Middle East.
"The next generation, even one removed, now are serving in the SAS."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The 2023 NBA Finals kick off at 10:30am AEST today, with the Denver Nuggets taking on the Miami Heat in a best-of-seven series. But behind the scenes, the league is looking into whether a referee has used a Twitter account to defend themself and other officials from online critiques. Eric Lewis, who had been chosen to officiate the finals in each of the last four NBA seasons, was not selected as one of the 12 referees for this year's finals. After some now-deleted tweets were revealed by a pair of Twitter users last week, the league opened an investigation into whether Lewis violated NBA rules by speaking about officiating in an unauthorised manner. It has not been determined if Lewis was using the account, which used the name "blair cuttliff". "Regarding Eric Lewis and the social media posts, we are continuing to review the matter and he will not be working the finals," NBA spokesman Mike Bass says. It remains unknown what discipline from the league that Lewis could face if he broke policy by discussing officiating matters openly without approval.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: As the NBA Finals begin, the league is looking into a referee's alleged tweets

children.content: The 2023 NBA Finals kick off at 10:30am AEST today
, with the Denver Nuggets taking on the Miami Heat in a best-of-seven series.
But behind the scenes,
the league is looking into whether a referee has used a Twitter account to defend themself
and other officials from online critiques.
Eric Lewis, who had been chosen to officiate the finals in each of the last four NBA seasons, was not selected as one of the 12 referees for this year's finals.

After some now-deleted tweets were revealed by a pair of Twitter users last week, the league opened an investigation into whether Lewis violated NBA rules by speaking about officiating in an unauthorised manner.

props.alt: A male basketball referee holds a ball and points during a game. Crowd behind him.

children.content: (AP: Frank Franklin II)
It has not been determined if Lewis was using the account, which used the name "blair cuttliff".
"Regarding Eric Lewis and the social media posts, we are continuing to review the matter and he will not be working the finals," NBA spokesman Mike Bass says.
It remains unknown what discipline from the league that Lewis could face if he broke policy by discussing officiating matters openly without approval.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The marriage of Jordan's Crown Prince Hussein, 28, and Saudi architect Rajwa Alseif, 29, has drawn a star-studded guest list including Britain's Prince William and his wife Kate, as well as US First Lady Jill Biden. The couple have been married in a palace ceremony attended by royals and other VIPs from around the world, as massive crowds gathered across the kingdom to celebrate the region's newest power couple. The bride, wearing an elegant white dress by Lebanese designer Elie Saab, arrived at Zahran Palace in a 1968 Rolls-Royce Phantom V custom-made for the crown prince's late great grandmother. The crown prince arrived earlier in full ceremonial military uniform with a gold-hilted saber.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: William and Kate attend wedding of Jordan's crown prince

props.alt: King Abdullah II and Queen Rania, all wearing formal attire, in the hallway of a building

children.content: King Abdullah II and Queen Rania greet Britain's Prince William and his wife, Kate, before the marriage ceremony.
(AP: Royal Hashemite Court)
The marriage of Jordan's Crown Prince Hussein, 28, and Saudi architect Rajwa Alseif, 29, has drawn a star-studded guest list
including Britain's Prince William and his wife Kate, as well as US First Lady Jill Biden
The couple have been married in a palace ceremony attended by royals and other VIPs from around the world, as massive crowds gathered across the kingdom to celebrate the region's newest power couple.
The bride, wearing an elegant white dress by Lebanese designer Elie Saab, arrived at Zahran Palace in a 1968 Rolls-Royce Phantom V custom-made for the crown prince's late great grandmother.
The crown prince arrived earlier in full ceremonial military uniform with a gold-hilted saber.

props.alt: A bride in a white dress and veil, and a groom in a military outfit, smile and wave standing out the top of a moving vehicle

children.content: Jordan's Crown Prince Hussein and Saudi Rajwa Alseif wave to well-wishers during their wedding ceremonies in Amman.
(AP: Nasser Nasser)
